content: If this is an IMAP account, Thunderbird saves the draft periodically. If the time to write the message is longer than the time to save a draft, thunderbird saves it again. If you take longer time to write the message, thunderbird continues periodically to save more drafts. when the message is finally sent, thunderbird issues the command to delete the draft, but can cause the other drafts to remain. You have to manually delete those. OR, you can set the drafts folder to be local, in which case this situation never materializes.
creator: davidsk

content: I cannot duplicate that. I have Segoe, for example, on both lists, and both full lists are available in compose pane and in settings pane. When you set the defaults in the Settings pane, did you set for Other Writing Systems as well as Latin?

creator: ConeWH

content:
There is a possibility, but it's tedious. If you have not compacted the folders, try this:

  1. click help>troubleshootinginformation
  2. scroll to 'profile folders' and click 'open folder'
  3. exit thunderbird
  4. you are now in the profile. If the messages were in an IMAP account (that's my guess), click the imapmail folder and then the account folder. you should see the folder with the missing messages, such as INBOX, INBOX.msf. Ignore the msf files.
  5. Open the file "Inbox" with Notepad or a similar text editor. ("INBOX" has no suffix; do not open "INBOX.msf.") Locate your deleted email by searching the document.
  6. Locate the line before your email text that reads "X-Mozilla-Status: 000X" (where 'X' is any character other than 0). Change the number to four zeros (″0000"). Repeat for all other messages. Save the document and exit Notepad
  7. Now, COPY the file to the Mail\Local Folders folder in the profile
  8. restart thunderbird and the messages should appear.
creator: davidsk

content:
I find that such hanging is rare, which suggest to me that there's some local factor that makes it worse for you. Some things you might look into...

- Could be one of your add-ons is misbehaving. Try disabling them or running Thunderbird in Troubleshooting Mode to see if the problem goes away.

- Disable Hardware Acceleration in Thunderbird - it can sometimes contribute to display or performance anomalies.

- Try excluding your Thunderbird profile from your antivirus.

But to address your original question, You can End Task from Windows Task Manager. Right-click on an empty spot on the Toolbar to find it. There may be multiple Thunderbird processes.
creator: rednoise

content:
If Firefox can't connect to their web mail site, that seems like a pretty clear indication that either they are having a problem or they have changed their server addresses. Does your email provider have a help/support page where you can check to see if the web mail site is up?

There are a few web site that can check to see if another site or domain is down. Google the phrase "is that web site down" and you'll find a few. The one I often use is called, "Is It Down Right Now."

Many ISPs that had provided email services are now subcontracting those services to third-party hosts. My ISP, Xfinity/Comcast, has announced that their email will be moving to Yahoo, though it hasn't happened yet. I don't find that these companies are necessarily very good at keeping their customers informed. I wonder if you may be caught up in the crossfire of one of these transitions?
creator: rednoise
